newsitem.title: INDIA: PRESS DIGEST - Indian newspapers - May 23.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Indian newspapers - May 23.

text.p: Following is a summary of major Indian business and political stories in leading newspapers prepared for Reuters by Business News and Information Services Pvt Ltd, New Delhi Tel:3324842, 3351006, 3761233 Fax:+91-11-3351006 Internet: biznis@giasbm01.vsnl.net.in
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
TOP STORIES
The Times Of India
OVER 40 KILLED AS QUAKE STRIKES CENTRAL INDIA

At least 40 people were killed and over 1,000 injured in a devastating earthquake which struck parts of Madhya Pradesh, in central India, including the city of Jabalpur. Thousands of houses were damaged. Tremors were felt in other parts of the state in the Narmada valley but no loss of life was reported from these places. The earthquake measured 6.0 on the Richter scale.
Business Standard
OIL POOL DEFICIT REDUCTION STRATEGY SOON

A set of eight options to tackle the oil pool deficit will be placed before Prime Minister Inder Kumar Gujral when he returns to the capital from the northeast on Friday. The prime minister has convened a meeting to finalise the option which will be presented before the ruling United Front's steering committee on Sunday. Most of these options are variations of different increases in prices of some petroleum products and a reduction in duties on others. The options were designed to tackle only the flow factor while leaving the stock factor to be taken care of at a later date.
The Economic Times
FUND FOR PROMOTING TEA BRAND ABROAD

The first funding from the India Brand Equity Fund will be provided to Projects India Blends, a company promoted by six top Indian tea companies including Tata Tea and Warren Tea. The funding will go to market a tea branded "Nargis", promoted by this company, in the Russian and other Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) markets. "Nargis" tea was launched in Russia last year and had already notched up sales of one million kilogrammes. The company hopes to intensify its market efforts in the CIS region and to replicate its strategy in other countries as well.
Financial Express
CABINET SET TO FUEL LPG-RUN CARS

A proposal to use liquid petroleum gas (LPG) as a fuel for automobiles is before the cabinet. Government sources said the bona fide use of LPG in vehicles already had the nod of the prime minister's office and was awaiting approval from the cabinet. The move came as a relief for the already thriving population of LPG-run vehicles. The industry ministry is already in the process of amending the gas cylinder usage rules for the oil industry in this connection.
PLEA FOR DUMPING DUTY ON COTTON FABRICS REJECTED

The European Union (EU) rejected the European Commission's (EC) move to slap modified anti-dumping duty on exports of unbleached cotton grey fabrics from India and five other countries. It came as relief to India as its exports of unbleached cotton grey fabrics to Europe amount to 6.5 billion rupees a year. The EC had imposed provisional anti-dumping duty ranging from 15.9 percent to 17.5 percent on unbleached cotton gray fabrics exports from India.
DEPARTMENT OF TELECOM PROPOSES MAJOR FINANCIAL SOPS

The Department of Telecommunications (DoT) has proposed major financial concessions to basic operators. This includes a reduction in the financial bank guarantee (FBG) and waiver of penal interest. The operators are asking for a reduction in the financial bank guarantee to the level of licence fee liability of the succeeding year.
UK BANK TO MARKET INDIAN TRADE PAPERS IN EUROPE

West Merchant Bank, a British-based financial intermediary, will be entering into a strategic alliance with the Export Credit & Guarantee Corporation (ECGC) to market Indian trade papers in Europe. The trade papers will be issued by the ECGC to cover the export risk of Indian entrepreneurs. The West Merchant Bank's move effectively will open up the secondary market at international level for Indian trade papers.
Business Standard
BALANCE SHEET DISCLOSURE NORMS FOR BANKS TIGHTENED

The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has decided to tighten the disclosure norms pertaining to provisions made by commercial banks. The banks will have to disclose up front the specific provisions made for non-performing assets, depreciation in the value of investments and, income tax. The RBI has also directed the banks to disclose their net non-performing assets as a percentage of their net advances. These measures are part of a series of steps to make the banks' accounting practices more transparent. All banks will have to follow the new norms while drawing up their balance sheets for 1996/97 (April-March).
RESERVE BANK PLANS SCRUTINY OF TOP NON-FINANCING BANKS

The Reserve Bank of India is considering a proposal to place large non-banking finance companies (NBFC) under special supervision. This is part of a series of measures to prevent a recurrence of the CRB Capital Markets type debacles. The supervision will be done by the RBI-appointed auditors. The RBI is also considering making a minimum credit rating mandatory for NBFCs which wanted to accept public deposits.
INFRASTRUCTURE STATUS SOON FOR PAGING INDUSTRY

The government may provide a series of concessions to the paging industry, including infrastructure status, reduction in excise duties and licence fees, a waiver of junction line fees and liquidated damages. This would revive the industry, which had been registering losses of 150 million rupees every month. The telecom secretary confirmed the Department of Telecommunications had recommended these to the Finance Ministry and that every industry that helped in the development of telecommunications should be recognised as infrastructure.
SONY MAY WITHDRAW IF BROADCAST BILL IS PASSED

Sony Corporation may pull out of its 60:40 entertainment venture if the broadcast bill is passed in its present form. The bill proposes to limit to 49 percent the holding of foreign investors in entertainment broadcasting companies. Sony Corporation has a 60 percent stake in Sony Entertainment Television, (SET). Sony has so far invested around two billion rupees in this venture. The operating officer of SET said if Sony has to lower its stake from 60 percent to 49 percent, it definitely will not have any interest in lending the brand name to its Indian venture.
SURETY QUOTA RIDER STALLS BHADRAVATI PROJECT FUNDING

The extension of a counter-guarantee by the federal government to the Dabhol power project has hit the other fast track power project in Maharashtra, Bhadravati. The federal government has refused to offer full counter guarantee to the Bhadravati project. Under the general parameters of counter-guarantees, the federal government's total exposure in a state can not exceed the sum total of the central plan assistance and the share of central taxes transferred to the state in the preceding financial year.
The Observer
STAKE IN DABHOL POWER PROJECT

The Maharashtra government is negotiating with Enron power corporation's Dhabol Power Company (DPC) to acquire a 30 percent stake in DPC. The Maharashtra State Electricity Board (MSEB), through a special purpose vehicle, is preparing to raise six billion rupees by private placement of bonds to enable it to subscribe to the equity, which at par value works out to about $96.84 million. The Dabhol Power Company has refused to divulge the amount of pre-operative expenses that would have to be borne by MSEB.
Business Line
MODEL PACT REVISED FOR BROKERS, SUB-BROKERS

The bourse regulator (SEBI) has revised the model agreement to be entered into between a broker and his/her sub-broker, based on suggestions received by it from the market participants. SEBI has asked the exchanges to follow it. According to the model, to transact through a stock broker, a registered sub-broker will have to be recommended by the stock broker with whom he/she was being affiliated. The sub-broker can get affiliated with more than one broker but will have to seek separate registration in each case. The sub-broker will have to mandatorily disclose the names of all other sub-brokers with whom he/she had a direct or indirect interest.
